posts.cooked:
Hi all!

For teams that use 2+ chassis during build season for development, how do you do it? I am really curious about how you manage students/subteams, your workflow, the balance between mechanical and control system time on each chassis, etc.  If you have any additional documentation I would love to see it too!

Thank you!

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: We make 3? One is a dev bot for programming, ie getting vision working on a new base, testing swerve gear ratios, and starting auto paths, The second one is the actual comp bot that has full functional mechanisms.  The third one is a kit bot for our rookie team to build and iterate off of.

posts.name: Ashton
posts.cooked: we just build two of them. the first one is deemed ‚Äúproto bot‚Äù its slapped together week 1 as a place to test things and figure out what wont work. This off-season we are making a steel chassis, this will be shop use only. it has a ton of mounting holes, and we can put anything anywhere. AFAIK this will be out new ‚Äúprotobot‚Äù chassis. it has also been named ‚ÄúD-Bot/Defense chasis) so Im assuming we may also use it during driver training. We are also a highly developed team about to start its 21st season, we have 20 years worth of resources at our disposal. it would be incredibly difficult for a rookie team to do that. HOWEVER it has been absolutly proven to be possible. Just look at 10014, they were a rookie team in texas, and a GOOD one at that. they IIRC they placed 2nd or 3rd at DCMP and they outperformed us at worlds. 2 chassis has worked for us, but we‚Äôve also been spending every friday and Saturday of build season at the shop until 3am.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 1730  your favorite redneck engineer. I do not speak for the team

posts.custom_user_title: 1730  your favorite redneck engineer. I do not speak for the team

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: We have done different things in past years and what we do next year entirely depends on how ‚Äúeasy‚Äù the game is. When bag day was a thing, we would consistently make both a ‚Äúpractice‚Äù and real robot that were mostly identical, and continued to try to follow this practice through the 2023 season. In '24 we switched to swerve, and although we only had 2 sets of swerve modules we technically used 3 chassis. In the first week of build season we converted our 2023 offseason bot into our prototyping robot that we used for initial testing, Later in the season (around week 4 of build) we made a ‚Äúbeta‚Äù robot that was basically an initial version of our final comp robot, and ran most of our programming and drive practice on that robot before switching to the more polished final version (which we took the modules for from our prototype robot) a little bit before competition. In 2025 which was a much harder game to design for, we initially were going to do the same schedule as 2024, including reusing the same 2023 offseason bot for our prototyping robot, but instead of making 2 separate beta and comp robots that existed independently we ended up swapping out all of the mechanisms on the beta robot for finalized versions over the last few weeks of build season until we ended up with our final comp robot. If next years game is a difficult pick and place, we might plan to do something more like 2025, whereas if we are confident we can get a simple robot out fast we might follow the 2024 schedule.

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked:
We have a mk4i chassis all wired up pre-season. Initially this was used for a off season robot used for training new students.

image 652√ó500 48.2 KB

image 652√ó500 48.2 KB

image 652√ó500 48.2 KB

We added vision and a kitbot frame so programming could get moving. This was added sometime early week one. It is still functional, and we actually plan to run it at an upcoming off-season.

image 1920√ó2557 878 KB

image 1920√ó2557 878 KB

image 1920√ó2557 878 KB

This year we were interested in using path planning during teleop - so this gave us a platform to work on that.  We will likely do something similar this year.

It‚Äôs not super labor intensive since it‚Äôs just a kitbot. We do have a fair amount of money tied up in the system, but luckily it can be reused.

posts.custom_user_title: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: It costs a little more but we decided to make two competitive teams for the two chasses. We split the students by grade. Now if we only had more mentors‚Ä¶ .

We made three chassis this year. Our situation was a little special, seeing that we just got a bunch of krakens. Previously we had more than enough falcons to build two, and we also just had our second best season ever (according to statbotics), due to the great mechanical students. I strongly recommend that you don‚Äôt make three, as it is expensive, hard to manage, and overall you spend so much time calibrating the three different robots that it does not make the difference.

posts.name: T.Krauter
posts.cooked: For this season, once we had a design we were generally happy with, we quickly manufactured a version of that design as quickly as possible.  No weight reduction on any of the tubes; get the robot together.  After testing on that robot and iterating on a few things, we started to build the final competition robot, with weight reduction and not quickly fabricated parts.  Both robots were kept together for most of the season, and any changes that we wanted to make to the comp bot were tested on the practice bot first, so that we wouldn‚Äôt change something on the robot going to competitions without knowing how it would impact the rest of the bot.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: We started doing 2 chassis during the bag era so we could do drive practice after bag day, but kept it up afterwards.  The build and drive teams swapped the chassis about weekly; the programmers supported both.  If you have more than a dozen members on the team, this paradigm allows both iteration and drive practice to happen full time after week 1 or 2.  At least once, we chose which robot went to competition the afternoon before. Protip: formally identify each chassis up front: A B, blue gold, green silver, whatever.  One year, the mechanical and programming teams had swapped labels.  The result was..less than optimal.

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: On my last team(6343), we built a swerve chassis in the offseason of 2022 to try and get swerve drive to work, which didn‚Äôt get finished for another 18 months. Then, in 2023, we built a tank drivetrain with the same dimension as our comp bot to test balancing autos. Then, in 2024, we used swerve drive for the first time(And it was just our luck that CTRE swerve generator came out right after we got swerve working), and used the swerve chassis to test autos, and we did the same with it in 2025.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked:
We built our first set of twin robots this year, since the end of bag-n-tag. Our alpha bot was used for initial iterating on systems to find flaws faster and also as a test bed for parts we might need on the Comp bot, if they broke. The goal was to have something we could swap for drive practice if there were repairs needed because we had lost practice time to that in previous years. What we hadn‚Äôt counted on was a game where the key game piece could destroy parts of the robot with a simple slip up. Failing to account for a Coral falling in just the wrong place would frequently damage our shooter, but because we had a twin we were usually able to replace it quickly or swap robots and then remake it. Also, not all improvements were tested on Alpha because it was already being used by drivers and Comp wasn‚Äôt ready until a day or so before Week 1. This led to us having an untested new cable-management system that didn‚Äôt handle the jolts of a match as well as we‚Äôd predicted it would.

We‚Äôre considering doing a second chassis again this year, but maybe scaling down expectations by only using the alpha build for initial iterating and early drive practice and/or programming without the need to build a twin. It will be done on the 2025 alpha chassis. Programming would use 2025 Comp for initial auto planning and drive-code updates, allowing for a multi-track effort.

For those who are building multiple chassis, how much of a consideration is there to ensure the multiple chassis are identical to each other, specifically with respect to swerve modules? For example, if I have one chassis with MK4 modules and another chassis with MK4i modules, would there be a push to make the 2nd chassis MK4 or MK4i since these modules have different geometries or do teams usually work with what they have and adapt their designs to whatever their competition chassis will be?

posts.name: T.Krauter
posts.cooked: From my team‚Äôs perspective, the more similar the two robots can be, the better.  If you can reduce the number of variables that your programmers have to consider when they are changing between robots in general, you will see more forward progress.  We have had some experience building and programming 2 drivetrains with different frame perimeters at the same time, but the modules were the same style and would have worked in the other drive base in a pinch.
